item.title: Intro to Methods for Writing the First Manuscript Draft

    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>Probably one of the most frustrating parts of the scientific writing process is actually getting words to paper, aka âthe first draftâ.</p>
<p>Itâs not uncommon (for me, anyway) that after finding the time and having the energy to put words to paper, they fail to present themselves. Itâs a frustrating feeling that can lead to doubting myself as both a writer and an academic.</p>
<p>I forget that the brain is like a muscle and that writing is a skill. Even the most skilled track and field athletes warm up differently to run the 100 meter dash than to throw the javelin. Furthermore, being skilled at both events requires an athlete to learn and apply two different sets of techniques.</p>
<p>A similar concept applies to being an academic and/or scientist.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Designing experiments, conducting experiments, and writing a manuscript are all essential skill sets that require distinct techniques.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>This is the beginning of a blog series that will explore and describe several methods and techniques (below) for approaching the drafting process. Some of these may work as âwarm ups'' to transition your brain to the writing process. Others will be techniques to be employed directly in the drafting step. None are meant to be mutually exclusive.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>The goal of this series is to provide academic writers, like yourself, with tools to personalize and improve the writing process.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>I encourage you to experiment with them, find what works for you, and then tell me about it. What worked? What didnât work? Why not? Perhaps your experience will make it into a future post. ;)</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Drafting Techniques and Methods:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_warm_up/">The Warm Up</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_method/">The Method</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/draft_methods_freewrite/">The Freewrite</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">The Outline</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">Refinery</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">The Jigsaw</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">The Spurt</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">The Incubation</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">Sessional</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">The Set Up</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="">Tips and Tricks</a></p>
</li>
</ul>

<script>
  (function(w, d, t, h, s, n) {
    w.FlodeskObject = n;
    var fn = function() {
      (w[n].q = w[n].q || []).push(arguments);
    };
    w[n] = w[n] || fn;
    var f = d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0];
    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');
</script>
<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>Deciding what to write about is generally pretty easy for a researcher. Hereâs my research topic. Read. Take notes. Write the manuscript. But approaching the prewriting and drafting stages of the writing process that way can waste precious time and energy, so here are a couple of things you can do to focus your prewriting.</p>
<p>Prewriting is the first step in your journey to a manuscript or review paper. It precedes the drafting stage and is the step that will likely take the longest. During prewriting you:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Decide what youâre going to write about,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Make an outline of your paper, and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Research and take notes, aka âreview the literatureâ.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>While it may seem straightforward (albeit overwhelming), the prewriting process is crucial to all following steps of the writing process. A haphazard approach to prewriting can result in:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Non-essential research,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Disorganized writing full of tangents, and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A longer/more difficult revision process.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>All of which add up to lost time and energy.</p>
<p>That means you need a solid prewriting strategy, which is determined in the first (seemingly shortest) action of the writing process: deciding your topic.</p>
<p>Here are two tips to focus your ideas during step one of prewriting.</p>
<h2 id="identify-the-central-message">Identify the central message.</h2>
<p>The central message is one or two sentences that identify what you want your reader to know when they are done reading your scientific text. Since these are for planning purposes, they are often jargon heavy and donât make it into your article intact. Instead, the central message helps guide you, the author, in identifying key information that needs to be included in your outline and literature review.</p>
<p>For instance, my dissertation work studied how the bacterium <em>Bacillus anthracis</em> gathered iron using a small molecule called a siderophore. Siderophores are exported and used to scavenge insoluble iron from the environment. One of the siderophores that <em>B. anthracis</em> uses is called petrobactin. So, when I was planning my dissertation defense the central message for my talk was:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>âPetrobactin is <a href="https://mbio.asm.org/content/9/6/e02079-18.abstract" target="_blank" rel="noopener">required for rapid sporulation</a> by <em>B. anthracis</em> and is <a href="https://mbio.asm.org/content/8/5/e01238-17.short" target="_blank" rel="noopener">exported by ApeX</a>, but petrobactin fragments can support <em>B. anthracis</em> disease.â</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Again, this is jargon heavy and did not become an explicit sentence in my defense. However, it narrows down the information that will be included. For instance, if Iâm discussing petrobactin use by <em>B. anthracis</em>, then I donât need to discuss other bacteria that may use petrobactin (which is important information for a review paper about petrobactin). Additionally, if Iâm focusing on the role of petrobactin in sporulation, then I can keep my discussion of spore germination to a minimum.</p>
<h2 id="identify-your-scientific-narrative">Identify your scientific narrative.</h2>
<p>The narrative is going to be the overarching structure of your paper. Like the central message, this is jargon heavy and will not be directly included in the body of your paper. However, it helps further guide you in determining the information that needs to be included and what information or concepts are tangential. The most generalized narrative structure was characterized by Randy Olson in his book <a href="https://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/H/bo21174162.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><em>Houston, We Have a Narrative</em></a>. Here, Olson describes the ABT narrative structure, which is:</p>
<p><strong>And,</strong>
<strong>But,</strong>
<strong>Therefore.</strong></p>
<p>While it appears unassuming, the ABT narrative has a lot to offer scientists. Thereâs too much to cover in this blog post, so hereâs an overview (an ABT workshop will be offered in the future). Most stories can be crafted with a single ABT wherein the AND lays the background information and context, the BUT introduces a conflict or something unexpected, and the THEREFORE describes a solution or conclusion.</p>
<p>For example, this article was drafted from a brief ABT narrative:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>A - What is prewriting AND what steps are generally included in the first stage,</p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p>B - BUT a poor prewriting strategy can cause problems,</p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p>T - THEREFORE, here are two key concepts (central message and ABT) to guide the author through the writing process more efficiently.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>If you look back at the overall structure of this blog post, you can see how my ABT forms the skeleton of the writing. Similarly, the ABT helps inform my overall outline, as well as what information is relevant or not. In the ABT, Iâve committed myself to tips that make prewriting more effective for an organized draft. That means Iâm not discussing how to manage references. While thatâs important and easily locating your references makes adding citations more efficient, it doesnât directly contribute to the organization of your writing.</p>
<p>However, each science story, or manuscript, requires two distinct narrative ABTs. The first is the Question ABT, which generally provides the skeleton of the introduction, rationale, and methodology of the study. The second is the Answer ABT, which describes and organizes the results and their discussion.</p>
<p>Going back to the example of my dissertation defense, the narrative describing my first research paper on export of petrobactin from <em>B. anthracis</em> was:</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Question:</strong></p>
<blockquote>
<p>Known siderophore-associated proteins are upregulated in low iron conditions AND some known siderophore exporters belong to these different transport protein families. BUT there are many potential siderophore exporters in <em>B. anthracis</em>. THEREFORE, we have developed a bioinformatics protocol to target potential petrobactin exporters.</p>
</blockquote>
<p><strong>Answer:</strong></p>
<blockquote>
<p>After screening many different potential exporters, petrobactin is exported from the ApeX protein AND accumulates in the cell pellet of ÎApeX mutants. BUT ÎApeX exports functional petrobactin fragments THEREFORE it can still cause disease in mice.</p>
</blockquote>
<hr>
<p>These ABTs helped identify the structure of the outline and was particularly helpful in deciding the order in which data should be introduced in the results section.</p>
<p>By identifying the central message and narrative of your scientific text, you can help eliminate tangential information. Additionally, having a handle on the eventual narrative of your research paper can prevent a dense, unorganized data-dump draft.</p>

item.title: Where to Start (and When to Stop) a Lit Review

    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);

    sn.async = true;

<p>When it comes to a literature review for thesis and article writing, everyone has the same three questions.</p>
<ol>
<li>Where do I start?</li>
<li>When do I stop?</li>
<li>How do I stay organized?</li>
</ol>
<p>Today, weâll cover some tips for answering the first two questions. Next weekâs post will address organizing sources.</p>
<h2 id="where-do-i-start-the-lit-review">Where do I start the lit review?</h2>
<p><strong>The big picture</strong> - Itâs important to first get a sense of the overall field, and where youâll begin with this depends on your level of experience in the field. If you are completely new to the field, then beginning with a relevant Wikipedia article may be right for you. Like academic literature, <a href="https://science.sciencemag.org/content/357/6351/557.2" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Wikipedia entries</a> have references which can point you to relevant articles in the literature. However, if youâre familiar with the field and havenât done an in depth literature review in it  yet, then reading both a dated (at least 5 to 10 years old) and a recent (in the last 1 to 2 years) review article can help you understand the overall progress of the field and identify important articles and themes. Finally, those with high experience and knowledge in the field may choose to begin by reviewing the most recent publications using Google Scholar or a similar source.</p>














<figure  id="figure-where-to-begin-a-literature-review-according-to-your-experience-in-the-field">
  <div class="d-flex justify-content-center">
    <div class="w-100" ><img alt="Where to begin a literature review, according to your experience in the field." srcset="
               /post/when_to_stop/getting_started_hu814c3514c9a5683f64f0cfd0704540bd_153939_39114ecd443bc34fefdfbd9c84e6a2d3.png 400w,
               /post/when_to_stop/getting_started_hu814c3514c9a5683f64f0cfd0704540bd_153939_392e119aa0126a61fd7c569dc183ad23.png 760w,
               /post/when_to_stop/getting_started_hu814c3514c9a5683f64f0cfd0704540bd_153939_1200x1200_fit_lanczos_3.png 1200w"
               src="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/when_to_stop/getting_started_hu814c3514c9a5683f64f0cfd0704540bd_153939_39114ecd443bc34fefdfbd9c84e6a2d3.png"
               width="760"
               height="313"
               loading="lazy" data-zoomable /></div>
  </div><figcaption>
      Where to begin a literature review, according to your experience in the field.
    </figcaption></figure>
<p><strong>The outline</strong> - Before you begin the literature review, you should have developed an <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/why_outline/">outline</a>. Now that you have an understanding of the big picture, re-evaluate the outline for missing pieces, logical flow, and potential redundancies. If things seem overwhelming, pick a topic or subtopic to begin your research at. You could either ease into the process by choosing a topic you know fairly well, or pick the area where you are the weakest and know you will need to spend the most time.</p>
<h2 id="when-do-i-stop-reading-and-start-writing">When do I stop reading and start writing?</h2>
<p><strong>Set a deadline</strong> - Consider allocating a specific amount of time to the initial research stage of your writing process. This may help you be more efficient with your research time and gives a non-negotiable deadline to start putting words to paper.</p>
<p><strong>Keep track</strong> - Keep a log or journal where you note the search terms and databases that you have used to find sources. Have you exhausted your options? If so, consider asking a colleague or your advisor if they have additional suggestions for search terms and/or resources. If not, or you feel confident with your search thus far, then it might be time to start your first draft.</p>
<p><strong>Update your outline</strong> - The outline should help guide your reading and information gathering, and should be updated as you work through each topic and subtopic. When each section seems to have a reasonable number of points, then you probably have enough information for the first draft.</p>
<p><strong>Check your mental load</strong> - Sometimes you will come across a new piece of information or perspective that will shift your thought process. Sometimes there will be so much information in your head that there doesnât seem to be room for any more. Any time there are thoughts that seem to be swirling, then itâs time to put them to paper. Maybe this means that after spending a few days on a subtopic your brain feels overwhelmed, so you stop and draft a few paragraphs before you move on to the next. Or maybe youâll research 50% or 90%, or even 100%, of the outline before this happens and you stop for a few days to get all of the information out of your head and onto paper. Either way, figuring out what works for you will give you a better idea of when itâs time to stop reading and start writing.</p>
<p><strong>Donât stress</strong> - Remember that <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/">writing is iterative</a> so you can always (and probably will) come back to the research stage later.</p>
<h2 id="resources">Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://libguides.uwf.edu/c.php?g=215199&p=1420520" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LibGuides: Literature Review: Conducting & Writing</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://www.scribbr.com/dissertation/literature-review/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Literature Review | A Complete Step-by-Step Guide</a> - Good tips for review papers</p>
</li>
</ul>

item.title: Why an Outline is Necessary for Science Writing

<script>
  (function(w, d, t, h, s, n) {
    w.FlodeskObject = n;
    var fn = function() {
      (w[n].q = w[n].q || []).push(arguments);
    };
    w[n] = w[n] || fn;
    var f = d.getElementsByTagName(t)[0];
    var v = '?v=' + Math.floor(new Date().getTime() / (120 * 1000)) * 60;
    var sm = d.createElement(t);
    sm.async = true;
    sm.type = 'module';
    sm.src = h + s + '.mjs' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sm, f);
    var sn = d.createElement(t);
    sn.async = true;
    sn.noModule = true;
    sn.src = h + s + '.js' + v;
    f.parentNode.insertBefore(sn, f);
  })(window, document, 'script', 'https://assets.flodesk.com', '/universal', 'fd');
</script>
<script>
  window.fd('form:handle', {
    formId: '[61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4]',
    rootEl: '.ff-61c280aed2fc90968d6f48e4',
  });
</script>

<p>The next step in the prewriting process is the outline, but what is it and why should you make one?</p>
<p>At this point, you should have your topic, <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/central_message_narrative/">central message, and narrative</a>. You will build on those to create an outline, the next layer in organizing your paper before you begin to write. But aside from personal preference, why create an outline at all?</p>
<p>To save yourself time and effort. The outline serves several purposes that all contribute to reducing the amount of revision your first draft will need.</p>
<p><strong>1. Reduce mental load.</strong></p>
<p>At this point, there are probably a lot of bits and pieces of your paper that are floating around in your head. The outline is a perfect place to keep these for future use. Getting them out and onto paper frees up a lot of brainspace, which youâll need for the research stage of prewriting. Additionally, the bullet point format will demonstrate the areas where you either have, or lack, expertise. And now you have a handy structure to add information <em>to</em> during your literature review to help track your progress .</p>
<p><strong>2. Improve organization.</strong></p>
<p>The bullet point format is also helpful for preempting repetitive information and making connections between topics to improve the overall flow of your manuscript. By outlining each section and their paragraphs first, you can ensure that each paragraph is essential in advancing your narrative and more easily identify (and rearrange) related information or logical connections to aid topic transitions. If youâre feeling stuck, there are outline prompts and resources at the bottom of the page.</p>
<p><strong>3. Ensure advisor compatibility.</strong></p>
<p>It can feel pretty defeating to write a 4,000 word first draft that your advisor either completely rearranges or scraps. Avoid that frustration for both you and your advisor by presenting them with a detailed outline. Going over the outline with your advisor can help eliminate potential problems by identifying areas that will need to be expanded, moved, or eliminated all together. Working with your advisor on the outline will also give both of you confidence in the drafting process, since you both have an understanding of what will be discussed and the order. To get the most out of the discussion, consider waiting until you have a more detailed post-literature review.</p>
<p>Remember, <a href="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/">the writing process is messy</a>, so your first outline wonât be perfect. Instead, much like your final product, it will be in constant flux until youâve moved past the revision stage. The upside is that itâs easier to change bulleted text instead of prose!</p>
<h2 id="outline-prompts">Outline Prompts</h2>
<p><strong>Introduction or Background</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>What information and/or context will the reader need to adequately understand everything that will be presented in the results?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What is the rationale for the study? What gap is it addressing?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What key techniques were used in the study?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Results (each subsection)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>What is the rationale for the experiment, what question will it answer?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What are the key points of setup that the reader needs to know to draw conclusions?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What are the possible conclusions from this experiment? What would the results be for each outcome?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What were the results?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What is your conclusion based on the described results?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Discussion or Conclusion</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Briefly, what were the major results and conclusions?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Put your findings in context with other studies, where do they line up or contradict?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What do these findings mean for the field at large?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What are the limitations to your conclusions?</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What do you want your reader to do and/or remember from your results?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="resources">Resources:</h2>
<ul>
<li>
<p><a href="https://uncw.edu/ulc/documents/organizationofanacademicpaper.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Organization of a Traditional Academic Paper</a></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://writingcenter.fas.harvard.edu/pages/outlining" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Outlining</a> - Good tips for organizing a review paper</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><a href="https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/general_writing/the_writing_process/developing_an_outline/how_to_outline.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">How to Outline</a></p>
</li>
</ul>

item.title: Scientific Writing is Messy. Thatâs Perfect.

<p>The scientific writing process can be summarized in five steps: prewriting, drafting, revising, editing, and finallyâ¦ publication. It seems straightforward, but also… overwhelming. Especially when youâre tasked with starting at the beginning.</p>
<p>The good news is that while writing is a lot of work, it can be made more approachable. This post is the first in a series that will explore the writing process and break it down into actionable pieces, with an emphasis on writing in the biological and biosciences.</p>
<p>Weâll begin by describing the overall writing process and workflow.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Prewriting - generate ideas, identify evidence and sources, and craft outlines</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drafting - transform the outline into logically connected sentences and paragraphs, add evidence</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Revising - reorganize the draft, add evidence, eliminate tangents</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Editing - correct misspellings and grammar, check citations and figures</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Publication - submit for grading (or peer review)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>And so, the general process appears to be linear.</p>














<figure  id="figure-what-we-think-the-writing-process-is-like-linear">
  <div class="d-flex justify-content-center">
    <div class="w-100" ><img alt="What we think the writing process is like. Linear." srcset="
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_0049405cc553350ed823b5900c083896.png 400w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_d68ab58266e02ccefd1577c5d368cbd7.png 760w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_1200x1200_fit_lanczos_3.png 1200w"
               src="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/writing_process_linear_hu505d8ad4a4021a1134ad263daf931d17_5271_0049405cc553350ed823b5900c083896.png"
               width="344"
               height="726"
               loading="lazy" data-zoomable /></div>
  </div><figcaption>
      What we think the writing process is like. Linear.
    </figcaption></figure>
<p>But in practice, the effective writing process is quite a bit messier (image 2). For instance, after writing a first draft, the author often identifies topics that need more elaboration and/or evidence, which send them back through the prewriting and drafting steps. Even after a manuscript is done and submitted to a research advisor or reviewer, it often comes back with requests for revision. To accomplish those revisions, the author may need to revisit the prewriting and drafting steps again, followed by revising and editing for resubmission.</p>














<figure  id="figure-a-better-representation-of-the-writing-process-iterative">
  <div class="d-flex justify-content-center">
    <div class="w-100" ><img alt="A better representation of the writing process. Iterative." srcset="
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_ba050413a17c9aac9341df1b6d94bdca.png 400w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_5e26e89e0405d74ff2613b8fc5e50362.png 760w,
               /post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_1200x1200_fit_lanczos_3.png 1200w"
               src="https://alliancescc.github.io/post/writing_process/writing_process_messy_hu737c7f8e29dd2bae9f0b8b1a5bf0de99_9007_ba050413a17c9aac9341df1b6d94bdca.png"
               width="586"
               height="609"
               loading="lazy" data-zoomable /></div>
  </div><figcaption>
      A better representation of the writing process. Iterative.
    </figcaption></figure>
<p>At first glance, the real writing process may seem even more overwhelming. After all, how are you supposed to know when to move forward or backward? How will you know when youâre done?</p>
<p>These are valid fears, and the beauty of an iterative writing process is that you donât really have to answer them. Approaching writing as an iterative process, as opposed to linear, has multiple advantages. Some of these include:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Reduced pressure for first drafts,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>More realistic writing expectations,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>More accurate writing timeline, and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Having sections in different stages of the process allows for workload flexibility.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scientific writing is an act of creativity that requires freedom to think, synthesize, and explore new ideas. Removing the pressure for the first draft to be perfect, or near perfect, allows you as a writer to start the writing process more creatively with bigger, messier ideas. As the ideas are refined, they might lead to unexpected connections and conclusions, but itâs hard to know unless they are given voice.</p>
<p>Additionally, because you begin the process knowing that prewriting, drafting, and revising will be revisited, there is less pressure for each step to be âcompleteâ before moving on to the next. Set goals for the amount of time of words that youâll spend on each step and when youâre done, start over. The more you write, the more accurate expectations you can develop for the time and effort spent at each step, leading to more accurate writing timelines.</p>
<p>An added bonus is that you can break down the writing task into smaller chunks, and work through the writing process for each individual section. If you have sections at varying stages (e.g., introduction is in prewriting, methods are in revising, discussion is in drafting), then you have freedom in the type of writing you will accomplish on any given day. Tired of putting words on the page? Read literature and work on prewriting the introduction. Mentally burnt out but still want to make progress? Add citations to the methods section.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>â Writing is not a linear process, like following a recipe to bake a cake.â Teaching Elementary School Students to Be Effective Writers, <a href="https://ies.ed.gov/ncee/wwc/Docs/PracticeGuide/writing_pg_062612.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Pg 14</a></p>
</blockquote>
<p>If the demands of a linear writing process seem overwhelming to you. Itâs understandable. Approaching writing as an iterative process may help overcome some of the mental obstacles in the way of your next writing task. This brief overview of the writing process will be followed by posts exploring each step in more detail and providing strategies to tackle them. For now, if your best laid writing plans arenât working out, donât feel alone. Writing is messy. And thatâs perfect.</p>
